articles.headline: Fad-Loving Japan May Derail a Sony Smartphone
articles.snippet: Sony, hoping to use smartphones to turn around its business, is facing the demands of Japan’s cellphone carriers for constant model updates.
articles.abstract: Sony, hoping to use smartphones to turn around its business, is facing the demands of Japan’s cellphone carriers for constant model updates.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Sony’s Xperia Z smartphone, which went on sale in February, has already sold almost a million units by some estimates. But NTT DoCoMo, Japan’s largest mobile carrier, will soon stop selling it.

articles.headline: In Bid for Keystone, Visions of a Greener Pipeline
articles.snippet: A race to develop cleaner technologies is one part of an industrywide campaign in Canada aimed at winning the Obama administration’s approval for a pipeline extension.
articles.abstract: A race to develop cleaner technologies is one part of an industrywide campaign in Canada aimed at winning the Obama administration’s approval for a pipeline extension.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHRISTINA LAKE, Alberta — After two years of study, President Obama this week defined the criteria for what will be one of the signature decisions of his presidency: the proposed Keystone XL pipeline that would carry heavy crude from here to American refineries must not “significantly” worsen global warming.

articles.headline: Mandatory Federal Cuts Hurt Private Sector, Too
articles.snippet: Many companies providing support services are cutting employees as work vanishes after federal spending was trimmed by $85 billion on March 1.
articles.abstract: Many companies providing support services are cutting employees as work vanishes after federal spending was trimmed by $85 billion on March 1.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress’s $85 billion, across-the-board budget cuts may not have brought the economy to a halt, as many once feared. But they are having a negative effect on jobs in the private sector, according to an analysis of the industries whose head count is most dependent on federal funds.

articles.headline: Counterfeit Food More Widespread Than Suspected
articles.snippet: Investigators have uncovered thousands of schemes involving counterfeit or adulterated food, some on an industrial scale and in developed countries.
articles.abstract: Investigators have uncovered thousands of schemes involving counterfeit or adulterated food, some on an industrial scale and in developed countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREAT DALBY, England — Invisible from the roadway, hidden deep in the lush English countryside, Moscow Farm is an unlikely base for an international organized crime gang churning out a dangerous brew of fake vodka.
articles.byline: By Stephen Castle and Doreen Carvajal

articles.headline: Cost of Public Projects Is Rising, and Pain Will Be Felt for Years
articles.snippet: The recent sell-off in bonds has hit hard in the municipal market, forcing governments to pay higher interest rates for crucial infrastructure projects.
articles.abstract: The recent sell-off in bonds has hit hard in the municipal market, forcing governments to pay higher interest rates for crucial infrastructure projects.
articles.lead_paragraph: States and cities across the nation are starting to learn what Wall Street already knows: the days of easy money are coming to an end.

articles.headline: Bill to Expand U.S. Database to Verify Hires
articles.snippet: The immigration overhaul making its way through the Senate contains an employment eligibility rule that could one day affect every American who takes a new job.
articles.abstract: The immigration overhaul making its way through the Senate contains an employment eligibility rule that could one day affect every American who takes a new job.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The sweeping immigration measure advancing rapidly in the Senate goes far beyond much-debated border security measures and a path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants with a crucial requirement that could affect every American who takes a new job in the future.
articles.byline: By Julia Preston and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Fed Officials Try to Ease Concern of Stimulus End
articles.snippet: In separate but similar speeches on Thursday, three officials from the Federal Reserve sought to reassure investors that economic data would continue to guide its actions on its stimulus campaign.
articles.abstract: In separate but similar speeches on Thursday, three officials from the Federal Reserve sought to reassure investors that economic data would continue to guide its actions on its stimulus campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economy is the victim of a little misunderstanding, Federal Reserve officials said on Thursday, telling investors who have sent borrowing costs soaring that they are misguided in believing the Fed’s stimulus campaign is about to wane.

articles.headline: Obama to Suspend Trade Privileges With Bangladesh
articles.snippet: The administration has come under intense pressure to suspend trade privileges with Bangladesh after one factory building collapsed in April and another burned in November.
articles.abstract: The administration has come under intense pressure to suspend trade privileges with Bangladesh after one factory building collapsed in April and another burned in November.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration on Thursday announced plans to suspend trade privileges for Bangladesh over concerns about safety problems and labor rights violations in the country’s garment industry.

articles.headline: In Mandela, Obama Found a Beacon Who Inspired From Afar
articles.snippet: President Obama, who has begun a weeklong trip to Africa, had been hoping to meet with the ailing Nelson Mandela, as he did in 2005, when he was a senator.
articles.abstract: President Obama, who has begun a weeklong trip to Africa, had been hoping to meet with the ailing Nelson Mandela, as he did in 2005, when he was a senator.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Barack Obama had been a United States senator for just weeks in early 2005 when Oprah Winfrey offered to carry a message for him to Nelson Mandela, the iconic South African leader.
